Homosexuality is wrong theologically, because it is pointless, and if everyone were gay, we wouldn't exist.
 Two fallacies right together. Sex is an expression of love and intimacy between persons and may be used for reproductive purposes, or for simply reinforcing pair-bonds and expressing love. This unitelelogical assumption is a fallacy stretching back to Aristotle, who argued that one of the four universal causes of things was a single teleological cause, the end to which those were put. Amusingly this fallacy is belayed by the very devices that we are using to communicate: computers trade on the design of the 'universal Turing machine', a device capable of performing a variety of functions, and consequently fulfilling a variety of ends and purposes. 
 
 I think it was David Hume, a buddy of Benjamin Franklin, who pointed out that you can't derive an 'ought' (or moral statement) solely from a set of 'is' (or empirical statements). Here's a link to help explain why this is: http://www.philosophypages.com/hy/4t.htm#intro 
 
 And perhaps unsurprisingly there are quite a few homosexuals who use sex to reproduce, either those who didn't notice anything odd about their lack of sexual interest in their opposite-sex spouse, or those who aren't willing to pay for in vitro fertilization when a few moments of social awkwardness is much cheaper. 
 
And homosexuality is wrong scientifically because sex is for generating new life, the penis is not designed for the anus, not to be beat off with the hand or mouth, that is a FACT!
 You're confusing sex with reproduction. In nature reproduction has been observed to happen either asexually or sexually. Similarly in nature sex has been observed to happen with and without reproduction. Moreover assigning teleological definitions to natural kinds is a fallacy - especially when those natural kinds and their functions are defined by some intentional scheme that exists above and beyond what is observed.

 No, you are right there, but it's also been pointed out that there is also more than one definition of the word Marriage as well. 
 
 Encarta Dictionary defines marriage like this:
 
 
marriage 
 
 
 
 
 mar·riage [ mérrij ] (plural mar·riages) 
 
 
 noun 
 
 1. legal relationship between spouses: a legally recognized relationship, established by a civil or religious ceremony, between two people who intend to live together as sexual and domestic partners
 
 
 2. particular marriage relationship: a married relationship between two particular people, or an individual's relationship with an individual spouse
 
 
 3. joining in wedlock: the joining together in wedlock of two people
 
 
 4. marriage ceremony: the ceremony in which two people are joined together formally in wedlock
 
 
 5. union of two things: a close union, blend, or mixture of two things
 Civilization is based on the marriage of tradition and innovation.
 
 
 6. card games king and queen of same suit: a combination of the king and queen of the same suit, in card games such as pinochle and bezique

 
 
 But Merriam-Webster defines it as such:
 
 
Pronunciation: 'mer-ij, 'ma-rij
 Function: noun
 Etymology: Middle English mariage, from Anglo-French, from marier to marry
 1 a (1) : the state of being united to a person of the opposite sex as husband or wife in a consensual and contractual relationship recognized by law (2) : the state of being united to a person of the same sex in a relationship like that of a traditional marriage <same-sex marriage< b : the mutual relation of married persons : WEDLOCK c : the institution whereby individuals are joined in a marriage
 2 : an act of marrying or the rite by which the married status is effected; especially : the wedding ceremony and attendant festivities or formalities
 3 : an intimate or close union <the marriage of painting and poetry -- J. T. Shawcross< 

 
 Note, even Merriam-Webster does infact identify alternate definitions that between "one man, one woman".
